clinical_study.brief_title: Dislocation Rates of Femoral Catheter Placed Sonographically Either In-plane or Out-of-plane
clinical_study.official_title: Dislocation Rates of Femoral Catheter Placed Sonographically Either In-plane or Out-of-plane: A Prospective Randomized Study

brief_summary.textblock: Dislocation of the femoral nerve catheters, which are used as postoperative analgesic method after knie surgery, will be studied. Two Groups will be compared; in the first group the femoral nerve catheter will be placed sonographically with the in-plane technique, whereas in the other Group the femoral nerve catheter will be placed sonographically with the out-of-plane technique

detailed_description.textblock:
Patients scheduled for elective major knee surgery will be assessed for eligibility and after written informed consent included in this clinical trial. Prior to surgery, the patient will receive a femoral catheter with either ultrasound placed in-plane (IP) or with ultrasound placed out-of-plane (OOP) as perioperative analgesic regimen using well-established and previously published techniques. The allocation to the different groups will be according to a computerized random-list established the day prior to surgery. In all cases, continuous regional anaesthesia regimen will be started after surgery. For surgery the patient can receive spinal anaesthesia, or a general anaesthesia. The use of a sciatic block will be applied according to the clinical standards of our department. Ropivacaine 0.3% (bag with 100 ml, Sintetica SA, Mendrisio Switzerland) 20 ml for the femoral catheter insertion. In both groups 10ml of ropivacaine 0.3% will be applied over the needle and 10ml over the catheter after its placement. In both groups the catheters will be connected to the electronic pump in the recovery room and run with ropivacaine 0.3% at 6 ml/h with boli of 4ml every 20min.
First rescue medication: ropivacaine 0.3% 20ml up to 3 x day. The catheters will stay in place for 48 hours and removed only if VAS< 40 with standard analgesia.
At 24 and 48 hours after placement of the femoral catheter, a bolus of NaCl 0.9% 10ml will be applied under ultrasound control in both groups and dislocation will be noted if the local anaesthetic does not reach the femoral nerve. In that case it will be noted where the local anaesthetic is localised. Block quality will be checked by applying cold on the front of the knee and measuring the sensation to cold in a scale from 0 to 2 (before NaCl 0.9% application). Pain will be assessed before the dislocation test only for in front and medial side of the knee in a regularly used NRS scale from 0 to 10. Complications and side effects of regional anesthesia in both groups will be documented (toxicity, blood in catheter, infection).

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: 1 Group will be compared to another
study_design_info.masking_description: The Patient will not be told in which Group he belongs

primary_outcome.measure: Dislocation of the femoral nerve catheter at 48 hours after its placement.
primary_outcome.time_frame: 48 hours after the placement of the catheter
primary_outcome.description: The catheter will be checked if in the right place using ultrasound location

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 30min (time needed to place and fix a femoral catheter)
secondary_outcome.description: Time to place the catheter measured in seconds

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 48 hours after the placement of the catheter
secondary_outcome.description: satisfaction of the Patient during the block procedure in a scale of 0 to 10 (0 being not satisfied at all and 10 being totally satisfied)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 30min (time needed to place and fix a femoral catheter and regognize if it works)
secondary_outcome.description: number of failed blocks needed to be repeated

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 30min (time needed to place and fix a femoral catheter and to decide if it was difficult)
secondary_outcome.description: difficulty placing the catheter under ultrasound control

secondary_outcome.measure: Effect of the femoral catheter on the sensory sensation
secondary_outcome.time_frame: at 24 hours and 48 hours after the femoral nerve catheter
secondary_outcome.description: cold (cold metal bar) and pinprick (atraumatic test, using a sharp tip): can the patient recognize cold and sharp during the femoral nerve block? Answers are yes or no.

secondary_outcome.measure: rescue boli given over the catheter in the 48 hours after its placement
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At 48 hours after the placement of the catheter
secondary_outcome.description: amount of local anaesthetic rescue boli given

secondary_outcome.measure: Dislocation of the femoral nerve catheter at 24 hours after its placement.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At 24 and at 48 hours after the placement of the catheter

arm_group.description: In this Group the femoral nerve catheter will be placed with the in-plane technique.
In this Group the femoral nerve catheter will be placed with the out-of-plane technique.

intervention.description: Placement of femoral nerve catheter under ultrasound control
Placement of femoral nerve catheter under ultrasound control

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
American Society of Anesthesiologists class I-III patients, both sexes
≥ 18 years old
- Patients are undergoing major knie surgery at our University Hospital with standard use of regional anesthesia techniques to provide analgesia
Exclusion Criteria:
- Contraindications or allergy to the use of local anesthetics or other drugs used in the study.
- Women who are pregnant or breast feeding
- Women who have the intention to become pregnant during the course of the study
- Lack of safe contraception, defined as: female participants of childbearing potential, not using and not willing to continue using a medically reliable method of contraception for the entire study duration, such as oral, injectable, or implantable contraceptives, or intrauterine contraceptive devices, or who are not using any other method considered sufficiently reliable by the investigator(s) in individual cases
- Patients with acute porphyria
- Inability to follow the procedures of the study, e.g. due to language problems, psychological disorders, dementia, etc. of the participant
- Participation in another study with investigational drug within the 30 days preceding and during the present study
- Previous enrollment into the current study
- BMI > 40
- Local inflammation in the inguinal area
- Patient refusal for regional anesthesia or participation in the study
- Enrollment of the investigator, his/her family members, employees and other dependent persons

overall_official.affiliation: Department of Anaesthesia, Intensive Care and Pain Medicine

responsible_party.investigator_title: PD Dr. med José A. Aguirre, MSc, Senior Consultant Anesthetist
